docs.title: Wine Cellar
docs.text: Wine Cellar is a self-hosted wine management app built with Django, designed for wine enthusiasts to track wines, store tasting notes, rate wines, and manage inventory. Whether you're a casual drinker or a connoisseur, this app helps organize your collection.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Wine Tracking: Record and review wines you've tasted.
  • Inventory Management: Monitor bottle stock levels.
  • Multi-User Support: Host for yourself and your friends.
  • Barcode Scanning: Easy adding and removing known wines by scanning their barcode.
  • Tasting Notes: Save aroma, flavor, and experience details.
  • Wine Ratings: Rate wines to track preferences.
  • Food Pairings: Add recommended food pairings.
  • Self-hosted: Full control over your data.
  • Drink By Reminder: Email reminder to drink a bottle before it goes off.

docs.title: Deployment
docs.text: The easiest way to run Wine Cellar is by using docker as described below.

docs.title: Development / Demo Mode
docs.text:
Note

Not for production use.

docs.title: Steps:
docs.text:
1. Copy the development environment configuration: 
    cp .env.dev-sample .env.dev
  2. Build the Docker image: 
    docker build -t wine-cellar-dev .
  3. Start the application: 
    docker compose up
  4. (optional): populate database with some sample data: 
    make docker-fixtures

docs.title: Production Setup
docs.text:
Note

This setup is under development. Proceed with caution.

Note

When using podman instead of docker you might have to add :z to the volumes to allow sharing them between containers and make SELinux happy.

docs.title: Option 1: Using a Reverse Proxy
docs.text:
Prerequisites:

  • A configured reverse proxy.
  • Properly set .env files.

docs.title: Steps:
docs.text:
1. Copy and configure environment files: 
    cp .env.prod.db-sample .env.prod.db
cp .env.prod-sample .env.prod
  2. Edit .env files with secure credentials.
  3. Start the production container: 
    docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml up
  4. Configure your reverse proxy to forward traffic to http://127.0.0.1:8085.

docs.title: Email Setup
docs.text:
Wine Cellar can send notification emails, including reminders for when a wine should be drunk by ("drink by" reminders).

To enable email notifications, configure the email backend and credentials in your .env-prod file:

DJANGO_EMAIL_HOST=smtp.example.com
DJANGO_EMAIL_PORT=587
DJANGO_EMAIL_HOST_USER=your@email.com
DJANGO_EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD=yourpassword
DJANGO_EMAIL_USE_TLS=
DJANGO_EMAIL_USE_SSL=
DJANGO_DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL=Wine Cellar <your@email.com>

Note

USE_TLS and USE_SSL are mutual exclusive, only one can be True

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Ensure your system has:

  • Python 3.x
  • Node.js (v14.x or higher recommended)
  • npm (comes with Node.js)

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/the-broke-sommeliers/wine-cellar.git
cd wine-cellar

docs.title: 2. Install Dependencies
docs.text: make install

docs.title: 3. Run the Development Server
docs.text:
make server

Access the app at http://127.0.0.1:8003/.

docs.title: 4. Watch for Changes
docs.text: make watch

docs.title: 5. Create an Admin User
docs.text:
source venv/bin/activate
python manage.py createsuperuser

docs.title: 6. Load Sample Data (Optional)
docs.text: make fixtures

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Storage system represents how bottles are organized physically — on racks, shelves, or in bins. There are two main types of storage in the Wine Cellar app:

  1. Unstructured (Unlimited Shelf)
  2. Structured (Grid Shelf with Rows & Columns)

docs.title: Shelf Concepts
docs.text:
A Shelf (or rack) is a container for bottles. It may be either:

  • Unstructured — a freeform space with no limits on capacity
  • Structured — a grid with fixed rows and columns

docs.title: Core Entities
docs.text: Entity Description Shelf / Rack Container for bottles Mode unstructured or grid Rows / Columns Grid dimensions (if structured) Slot / Cell Individual position in a grid shelf Bottle A stored instance of a wine in a given location

docs.title: 1. Unstructured / Unlimited Shelf
docs.text: Unstructured shelves act like bins, crates or a fridge — you can add as many bottles as you like without worrying about coordinates.

docs.title: Characteristics
docs.text:
• No defined rows or columns
  • Effectively unlimited capacity
  • Perfect for bulk or casual storage

docs.title: Example: “Bulk Shelf”
docs.text:
Shelf A (mode: unstructured)

Wine Row Column Château Margaux 2015 Penfolds Grange 2014

docs.title: 2. Structured / Grid Shelf (Rows × Columns)
docs.text: Structured shelves define a clear grid — each bottle sits in a specific slot (row and column). This is perfect for users who want to know exactly where each bottle is stored.

docs.title: Characteristics
docs.text:
• Fixed number of rows and columns
  • Each slot holds exactly one bottle
  • Prevents overfilling or duplicates
  • Makes locating a bottle easy

docs.title: Example: “Main Rack”
docs.text:
Kitchen Rack (mode: structured, 4 rows × 5 columns)

Wine Row Column Château Margaux 2015 1 1 Château Margaux 2015 1 2 Dom Pérignon 2012 1 3 Penfolds Grange 2014 2 1

docs.title: Running the Test Suite
docs.text:
To execute all tests (backend and frontend), use:

make test

docs.title: Running Backend Tests
docs.text:
For Django tests, run:

python manage.py test

docs.title: Running Frontend Tests
docs.text:
To run JavaScript-based frontend tests, use:

npm test

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: A Wine represents a unique wine type or label — identified by key attributes like grapes, vintage, vinyard. Wines are templates for real bottles, which reference them when stored in the cellar.

docs.title: Wine vs Bottle
docs.text:
It’s important to distinguish between a Wine and a Bottle:

Concept Description Wine Metadata about a particular label or type of wine Bottle A specific instance of a wine in your cellar inventory

A single Wine record may have many bottles stored across different shelves or racks.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
You might have:

  • Wine: Château Margaux 2015
  • 12 Bottle entries linked to it, each with a defined storage location.

This separation allows you to:

  • Keep clean records of your cellar contents
  • Manage bottles individually
  • Track vintages, tasting notes, and inventory history
